Award.AwardTitle: Integrative biology of social cognition -- avpr1a, memory and alternative male tactics
Award.AbstractNarration: In the proposed research, the researchers use a well-studied model, the monogamous prairie vole, to understand the links between DNA variation, brain variation, social cognition and natural selection. Although prairie voles are monogamous, there is substantial variation in how widely males roam and in how faithful they are to a partner. Social behavior is widely known to influenced by the hormone vasopressin through actions on its receptor, V1aR; male mate fidelity is linked to V1aR abundance in specific parts of the brain known as the retrosplenial cortex (RSC) which is also critical in spatial memory. The proposal asks how individual differences in genotype, neuronal gene expression and social cognition interact with evolutionary forces to explain behavioral diversity. Specifically, the investigators ask whether individual differences in genotype, V1aR in the retropsplenial cortex and social cognition are maintained by density-dependent selection. These experiments will determine whether natural environments promote diversity in the social brain. The proposed work deepens and extends a research narrative on prairie vole monogamy that is well covered in textbooks for introductory biology, animal behavior and behavioral neuroendocrinology courses. The parallel examination of genetics, neurobiology, memory and fitness would provide a particularly complete picture of how evolutionary and mechanistic forces interact to shape animal behavior in the wild. The researchers will augment ongoing outreach activities with the development of a blog focused on the integrative study of animal behavior, its mechanisms and their evolution. The blog will enhance training by providing an opportunity for graduate students to hone communication skills, and by generating content accessible to a broad audience. It will deepen participation of under-represented groups by actively recruiting readers and writers through existing networks of minority scientists; it will facilitate the dissemination research findings through social media; and it will provide an infrastructure for the informal exchange of ideas among scientists and society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our project was focused on understanding how individual differences in hormones, brains and behavior translate into variation in complex behavior in the wild. Our work focuses on individual differences in the formation and expression of pair-bonds in the monogamous Midwestern rodent, the prairie vole, Microtus ochrogaster. At the heart of the grant is a series of field studies designed to look at the interactions between females, males and their neighbors. Pair-bonded males and females are territorial, but sometimes leave a territory to forage, and although they are paired, they sometimes mate with neighbors. We found that individual differences in male social and sexual fidelity were related to the expression of a specific hormone receptor.

Variation in the abundance of the vasopressin 1a receptor within a brain region critical for spatial memory – the retrosplenial cortex – strongly predicts whether males will intrude on the territories of neighbors or stick near their mates. We hypothesize that males with high levels of receptor are better able to keep track of their mates, and better able to avoid aggressive neighbors, leading to increases in fidelity. We found that this brain variation in turn depends on specific DNA sequence variation in the avpr1a gene. Analysis of the gene revealed that high-expressing alleles do well when the environment favors fidelity, and low-expressing variants do well when it favors infidelity. The DNA sequence variation is localized to a region of the genome that seems to regulate the abundance of the hormone receptor. Lastly, the DNA sequence variation at the avpr1a gene reveals a long history of selection that has actively maintained diversity in brain and behavior. Overall, our results suggest that the variation in the social brain is not necessarily noise or disease, but that differences in social behavior can be maintained by natural selection. This provides fundamental new insights into understanding the role of genetic variation in the function of the social brain.

This two-year grant led to a total of 9 papers that are published or in press, 2 that are currently in review, and 3 that are near submission. The bulk of the analysis from our extensive field studies, however, will unfold over the next few years, as we refine our tools for analyzing novel automated radio-telemetry data and couple these to the analyses of genetic and brain data. Thus we expect roughly 6 or so additional papers to come from this data set.

To effectively disseminate our findings to a lay audience, we teamed up with the University of Texas College of Natural Sciences Communications Office, who wrote a press release based on our findings. As a result, a paper published in Science in December 2015 received wide spread and accurate press coverage. In fact, it was reported on in 24 papers and magazines from around the world, from the New York Times to Glamour Magazine, making it the most widely reported story to come from the University of Texas in 2015. Altmetrics, a website that collates press and social media coverage, found that its impact was in the top 1% of all research outputs ever measured. Atlantic writer Ed Yong described the paper as weaving “threads that connect genetics, neuroscience, psychology, and evolutionary biology…a bravura piece of work.” In addition to this coverage, the piece was selected as the single most outstanding piece of research to be published from the University of Texas in the 2015/2016 academic year.

In addition, the PI Phelps has written pieces on social neuroscience and evolution for a lay audience. One of these pieces appeared in the Atlantic magazine, where it received 40,000 page views and 2600 Facebook shares. A second appeared in magazine Aeon, where it received 50,000 page views and 2300 Facebook shares. In addition, each of these publications was accompanied by thousands of users coming to the lab web page to read about our NSF-funded research. Although writing for a lay audience has been a primary mode of disseminating our findings to the general public, the Phelps Lab also has been extensively involved in a variety of outreach activities. Graduate students in the lab have for years been running a weekly seminar series at the UT field facility titled Science Under the Stars. The lab’s graduate students have also founded and contributed to a weekly radio and podcast show, They Blinded Me With Science. Lastly, the grant has enabled the training of a diverse array of graduate, undergraduate, and high school students. Resulting in trainees who have gone on to postdoctoral positions, to graduate and medical school, and to college – their experiences enriched by the opportunity to become authors on original scientific research.
